title: Definitions
prose:
1. A solid is a (figure) having length and breadth and depth.

2. The extremity of a solid (is) a surface.

3. A straight-line is at right-angles to a plane when it makes right-angles with all of the straight-lines joined to it which are also in the plane.

4. A plane is at right-angles to a(nother) plane when (all of) the straight-lines drawn in one of the planes, at right-angles to the common section of the planes, are at right-angles to the remaining plane.

5. The inclination of a straight-line to a plane is the angle contained by the drawn and standing (straight-lines), when a perpendicular is lead to the plane from the end of the (standing) straight-line raised (out of the plane), and a straight-line is (then) joined from the point (so) generated to the end of the (standing) straight-line (lying) in the plane.

6. The inclination of a plane to a(nother) plane is the acute angle contained by the (straight-lines), (one) in each of the planes, drawn at right-angles to the common segment (of the planes), at the same point.

7. A plane is said to have been similarly inclined to a plane, as another to another, when the aforementioned angles of inclination are equal to one another.

8. Parallel planes are those which do not meet (one another).

9. Similar solid figures are those contained by equal numbers of similar planes (which are similarly arranged).

10. But equal and similar solid figures are those contained by similar planes equal in number and in magnitude (which are similarly arranged).

11. A solid angle is the inclination (constituted) by more than two lines joining one another (at the same point), and not being in the same surface, to all of the lines.
Otherwise, a solid angle is that contained by more than two plane angles, not being in the same plane, and constructed at one point.

12. A pyramid is a solid figure, contained by planes, (which is) constructed from one plane to one point.

13. A prism is a solid figure, contained by planes, of which the two opposite (planes) are equal, similar, and parallel, and the remaining (planes are) parallelograms.

14. A sphere is the figure enclosed when, the diameter of a semicircle remaining (fixed), the semicircle is carried around, and again established at the same (position) from which it began to be moved.

15. And the axis of the sphere is the fixed straight-line about which the semicircle is turned.

16. And the center of the sphere is the same as that of the semicircle.

17. And the diameter of the sphere is any straight-line which is drawn through the center and terminated in both directions by the surface of the sphere.

18. A cone is the figure enclosed when, one of the sides of a right-angled triangle about the right-angle remaining (fixed), the triangle is carried around, and again established at the same (position) from which it began to be moved.
And if the fixed straight-line is equal to the remaining (straight-line) about the right-angle, (which is) carried around, then the cone will be right-angled, and if less, obtuse-angled, and if greater, acute-angled.

19. And the axis of the cone is the fixed straight-line about which the triangle is turned.

20. And the base (of the cone is) the circle described by the (remaining) straight-line (about the right-angle which is) carried around (the axis).

21. A cylinder is the figure enclosed when, one of the sides of a right-angled parallelogram about the right-angle remaining (fixed), the parallelogram is carried around, and again established at the same (position) from which it began to be moved.

22. And the axis of the cylinder is the stationary straight-line about which the parallelogram is turned.

23. And the bases (of the cylinder are) the circles described by the two opposite sides (which are) carried around.

24. Similar cones and cylinders are those for which the axes and the diameters of the bases are proportional.

25. A cube is a solid figure contained by six equal squares.

26. An octahedron is a solid figure contained by eight equal and equilateral triangles.

27. An icosahedron is a solid figure contained by twenty equal and equilateral triangles.

28. A dodecahedron is a solid figure contained by twelve equal, equilateral, and equiangular pentagons.

title: Proposition 1
prose:
Some part of a straight-line cannot be in a reference plane, and some part in a more elevated (plane).
For, if possible, let some part, {AB line}, of the straight-line {ABC line} be in a reference plane, and some part, {BC line}, in a more elevated (plane).

In the reference plane, there will be some straight-line continuous with, and straight-on to, {AB line}.
Let it be {BD line}.
Thus, {AB line} is a common segment of the two (different) straight-lines {ABC line} and {ABD line}.
The very thing is impossible, inasmuch as if we draw a circle with center {B point} and radius {AB line} then the diameters ({ABD line} and {ABC line}) will cut off unequal circumferences of the circle.

Thus, some part of a straight-line cannot be in a reference plane, and (some part) in a more elevated (plane).
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 2
prose:
If two straight-lines cut one another then they are in one plane, and every triangle (formed using segments of both lines) is in one plane.

For let the two straight-lines {AB line} and {CD line} have cut one another at point {E point}.
I say that {AB line} and {CD line} are in one plane, and that every triangle (formed using segments of both lines) is in one plane.

For let the random points {F point} and {G point} have been taken on {EC line} and {EB line} (respectively).
And let {CB line} and {FG line} have been joined, and let {FH line} and {GK line} have been drawn across.
I say, first of all, that triangle {ECB polygon} is in one (reference) plane.
For if part of triangle {ECB polygon}, either {FHC polygon} or {GBK polygon}, is in the reference [plane], and the remainder in a different (plane) then a part of one the straight-lines {EC line} and {EB line} will also be in the reference plane, and (a part) in a different (plane).
And if the part {FCBG polygon} of triangle {ECB polygon} is in the reference plane, and the remainder in a different (plane) then parts of both of the straight-lines {EC line} and {EB line} will also be in the reference plane, and (parts) in a different (plane).
The very thing was shown to be absurb [Prop. 11.1].
Thus, triangle {ECB polygon} is in one plane.
And in whichever (plane) triangle {ECB polygon} is (found), in that (plane) {EC line} and {EB line} (will) each also (be found).
And in whichever (plane) {EC line} and {EB line} (are) each (found), in that (plane) {AB line} and {CD line} (will) also (be found) [Prop. 11.1].
Thus, the straight-lines {AB line} and {CD line} are in one plane, and every triangle (formed using segments of both lines) is in one plane.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 3
prose:
If two planes cut one another then their common section is a straight-line.

For let the two planes {AB polygon} and {BC polygon} cut one another, and let their common section be the line {DB line}.
I say that the line {DB line} is straight.

For, if not, let the straight-line {DEB given} have been joined from {D point} to {B point} in the plane {AB polygon}, and the straight-line {DFB given} in the plane {BC polygon}.
So two straight-lines, {DEB given} and {DFB given}, will have the same ends, and they will clearly enclose an area.
The very thing (is) absurd.
Thus, {DEB given} and {DFB given} are not straight-lines.
So, similarly, we can show than no other straight-line can be joined from {D point} to {B point} except {DB line}, the common section of the planes {AB polygon} and {BC polygon}.

Thus, if two planes cut one another then their common section is a straight-line.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 4
prose:
If a straight-line is set up at right-angles to two straight-lines cutting one another, at the common point of section, then it will also be at right-angles to the plane (passing) through them (both).

For let some straight-line {EF line} have (been) set up at right-angles to two straight-lines, {AB line} and {CD line}, cutting one another at point {E point}, at {E point}.
I say that {EF line} is also at right-angles to the plane (passing) through {AB line} and {CD line}.

For let {AE line}, {EB line}, {CE line} and {ED line} have been cut off from (the two straight-lines so as to be) equal to one another.
And let {GEH line} have been drawn, at random, through {E point} (in the plane passing through {AB line} and {CD line}).
And let {AD line} and {CB line} have been joined.
And, furthermore, let {FA line}, {FG line}, {FD line}, {FC line}, {FH line}, and {FB line} have been joined from the random (point) {F point} (on {EF line}).

For since the two (straight-lines) {AE line} and {ED line} are equal to the two (straight-lines) {CE line} and {EB line}, and they enclose equal angles [Prop. 1.15], the base {AD line} is thus equal to the base {CB line}, and triangle {AED polygon} will be equal to triangle {CEB polygon} [Prop. 1.4].
Hence, the angle {DAE angle} [is] equal to the angle {EBC angle}.
And the angle {AEG angle} (is) also equal to the angle {BEH angle} [Prop. 1.15].
So {AGE polygon} and {BEH polygon} are two triangles having two angles equal to two angles, respectively, and one side equal to one side---(namely), those by the equal angles, {AE line} and {EB line}.
Thus, they will also have the remaining sides equal to the remaining sides [Prop. 1.26].
Thus, {GE line} (is) equal to {EH line}, and {AG line} to {BH line}
And since {AE line} is equal to {EB line}, and {FE line} is common and at right-angles, the base {FA line} is thus equal to the base {FB line} [Prop. 1.4].
So, for the same (reasons), {FC line} is also equal to {FD line}.
And since {AD line} is equal to {CB line}, and {FA line} is also equal to {FB line}, the two (straight-lines) {FA line} and {AD line} are equal to the two (straight-lines) {FB line} and {BC line}, respectively.
And the base {FD line} was shown (to be) equal to the base {FC line}.
Thus, the angle {FAD angle} is also equal to the angle {FBC angle} [Prop. 1.8].
And, again, since {AG line} was shown (to be) equal to {BH line}, but {FA line} (is) also equal to {FB line}, the two (straight-lines) {FA line} and {AG line} are equal to the two (straight-lines) {FB line} and {BH line} (respectively).
And the angle {FAG angle} was shown (to be) equal to the angle {FBH angle}.
Thus, the base {FG line} is equal to the base {FH line} [Prop. 1.4].
And, again, since {GE line} was shown (to be) equal to {EH line}, and {EF line} (is) common, the two (straight-lines) {GE line} and {EF line} are equal to the two (straight-lines) {HE line} and {EF line} (respectively).
And the base {FG line} (is) equal to the base {FH line}.
Thus, the angle {GEF angle} is equal to the angle {HEF angle} [Prop. 1.8].
Each of the angles {GEF angle} and {HEF angle} (are) thus right-angles [Def. 1.10].
Thus, {FE line} is at right-angles to {GH line}, which was drawn at random through {E point} (in the reference plane passing though {AB line} and {CD line}).
So, similarly, we can show that {FE line} will make right-angles with all straight-lines joined to it which are in the reference plane.
And a straight-line is at right-angles to a plane when it makes right-angles with all straight-lines joined to it which are in the plane [Def. 11.3].
Thus, {FE line} is at right-angles to the reference plane.
And the reference plane is that (passing) through the straight-lines {AB line} and {CD line}.
Thus, {FE line} is at right-angles to the plane (passing) through {AB line} and {CD line}.

Thus, if a straight-line is set up at right-angles to two straight-lines cutting one another, at the common point of section, then it will also be at right-angles to the plane (passing) through them (both).
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 5
prose:
If a straight-line is set up at right-angles to three straight-lines cutting one another, at the common point of section, then the three straight-lines are in one plane.

For let some straight-line {AB line} have been set up at right-angles to three straight-lines {BC line}, {BD line}, and {BE line}, at the (common) point of section {B point}.
I say that {BC line}, {BD line}, and {BE line} are in one plane.

For (if) not, and if possible, let {BD line} and {BE line} be in the reference plane, and {BC line} in a more elevated (plane).
And let the plane through {AB line} and {BC line} have been produced.
So it will make a straight-line as a common section with the reference plane [Def. 11.3].
Let it make {BF line}.
Thus, the three straight-lines {AB line}, {BC line}, and {BF line} are in one plane—(namely), that drawn through {AB line} and {BC line}.
And since {AB line} is at right-angles to each of {BD line} and {BE line}, {AB line} is thus also at right-angles to the plane (passing) through {BD line} and {BE line} [Prop. 11.4].
And the plane (passing) through {BD line} and {BE line} is the reference plane.
Thus, {AB line} is at right-angles to the reference plane.
Hence, {AB line} will also make right-angles with all straight-lines joined to it which are also in the reference plane [Def. 11.3].
And {BF line}, which is in the reference plane, is joined to it.
Thus, the angle {ABF angle} is a right-angle.
And {ABC angle} was also assumed to be a right-angle.
Thus, angle {ABF angle} (is) equal to {ABC angle}.
And they are in one plane.
The very thing is impossible.
Thus, {BC line} is not in a more elevated plane.
Thus, the three straight-lines {BC line}, {BD line}, and {BE line} are in one plane.

Thus, if a straight-line is set up at right-angles to three straight-lines cutting one another, at the (common) point of section, then the three straight-lines are in one plane.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 6
prose:
If two straight-lines are at right-angles to the same plane then the straight-lines will be parallel.

For let the two straight-lines {AB line} and {CD line} be at right-angles to a reference plane.
I say that {AB line} is parallel to {CD line}.

For let them meet the reference plane at points {B point} and {D point} (respectively). And let the straight-line {BD line} have been joined.
And let {DE line} have been drawn at right-angles to {BD line} in the reference plane.
And let {DE line} be made equal to {AB line}.
And let {BE line}, {AE line}, and {AD line} have been joined.

And since {AB line} is at right-angles to the reference plane, it will [thus] also make right-angles with all straight-lines joined to it which are in the reference plane [Def. 11.3].

And {BD line} and {BE line}, which are in the reference plane, are each joined to {AB line}.
Thus, each of the angles {ABD angle} and {ABE angle} are right-angles.
So, for the same (reasons), each of the angles {CDB angle} and {CDE angle} are also right-angles.
And since {AB line} is equal to {DE line}, and {BD line} (is) common, the two (straight-lines) {AB line} and {BD line} are equal to the two (straight-lines) {ED line} and {DB line} (respectively).
And they contain right-angles.
Thus, the base {AD line} is equal to the base {BE line} [Prop. 1.4].
And since {AB line} is equal to {DE line}, and {AD line} (is) also (equal) to {BE line}, the two (straight-lines) {AB line} and {BE line} are thus equal to the two (straight-lines) {ED line} and {DA line} (respectively).
And their base {AE line} (is) common.
Thus, angle {ABE angle} is equal to angle {EDA angle} [Prop. 1.8].
And {ABE angle} (is) a right-angle.
Thus, {EDA angle} (is) also a right-angle.
{ED line} is thus at right-angles to {DA line}.
And it is also at right-angles to each of {BD line} and {DC line}.
Thus, {ED line} is standing at right-angles to the three straight-lines {BD line}, {DA line}, and {DC line} at the (common) point of section.
Thus, the three straight-lines {BD line}, {DA line}, and {DC line} are in one plane [Prop. 11.5].
And in which(ever) plane {DB line} and {DA line} (are found), in that (plane) {AB line} (will) also (be found).
For every triangle is in one plane [Prop. 11.2].
And each of the angles {ABD angle} and {BDC angle} is a right-angle.
Thus, {AB line} is parallel to {CD line} [Prop. 1.28].

Thus, if two straight-lines are at right-angles to the same plane then the straight-lines will be parallel.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 7
prose:
If there are two parallel straight-lines, and random points are taken on each of them, then the straight-line joining the two points is in the same plane as the parallel (straight-lines).

Let {AB line} and {CD line} be two parallel straight-lines, and let the random points {E point} and {F point} have been taken on each of them (respectively).
I say that the straight-line joining points {E point} and {F point} is in the same (reference) plane as the parallel (straight-lines).

For (if) not, and if possible, let it be in a more elevated (plane), such as {EGF given}.
And let a plane have been drawn through {EGF given}.
So it will make a straight cutting in the reference plane [Prop. 11.3].
Let it make {EF line}.
Thus, two straight-lines (with the same end-points), {EGF given} and {EF line}, will enclose an area.
The very thing is impossible.
Thus, the straight-line joining {E point} to {F point} is not in a more elevated plane.
The straight-line joining {E point} to {F point} is thus in the plane through the parallel (straight-lines) {AB line} and {CD line}.

Thus, if there are two parallel straight-lines, and random points are taken on each of them, then the straight-line joining the two points is in the same plane as the parallel (straight-lines).
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 8
prose:
If two straight-lines are parallel, and one of them is at right-angles to some plane, then the remaining (one) will also be at right-angles to the same plane.

Let {AB line} and {CD line} be two parallel straight-lines, and let one of them, {AB line}, be at right-angles to a reference plane.
I say that the remaining (one), {CD line}, will also be at right-angles to the same plane.

For let {AB line} and {CD line} meet the reference plane at points {B point} and {D point} (respectively).
And let {BD line} have been joined.
{AB line}, {CD line}, and {BD line} are thus in one plane [Prop. 11.7].
Let {DE line} have been drawn at right-angles to {BD line} in the reference plane, and let {DE line} be made equal to {AB line}, and let {BE line}, {AE line}, and {AD line} have been joined.

And since {AB line} is at right-angles to the reference plane, {AB line} is thus also at right-angles to all of the straight-lines joined to it which are in the reference plane [Def. 11.3].
Thus, the angles {ABD angle} and {ABE angle} [are] each right-angles.
And since the straight-line {BD line} has met the parallel (straight-lines) {AB line} and {CD line}, the (sum of the) angles {ABD angle} and {CDB angle} is thus equal to two right-angles [Prop. 1.29].
And {ABD angle} (is) a right-angle.
Thus, {CDB angle} (is) also a right-angle.
{CD line} is thus at right-angles to {BD line}.
And since {AB line} is equal to {DE line}, and {BD line} (is) common, the two (straight-lines) {AB line} and {BD line} are equal to the two (straight-lines) {ED line} and {DB line} (respectively).
And angle {ABD angle} (is) equal to angle {EDB angle}.
For each (is) a right-angle.
Thus, the base {AD line} (is) equal to the base {BE line} [Prop. 1.4].
And since {AB line} is equal to {DE line}, and {BE line} to {AD line}, the two (sides) {AB line}, {BE line} are equal to the two (sides) {ED line}, {DA line}, respectively.
And their base {AE line} is common.
Thus, angle {ABE angle} is equal to angle {EDA angle} [Prop. 1.8].
And {ABE angle} (is) a right-angle.
{EDA angle} (is) thus also a right-angle.
Thus, {ED line} is at right-angles to {AD line}.
And it is also at right-angles to {DB line}.
Thus, {ED line} is also at right-angles to the plane through {BD line} and {DA line} [Prop. 11.4].
And {ED line} will thus make right-angles with all of the straight-lines joined to it which are also in the plane through {BDA polygon}.
And {DC line} is in the plane through {BDA polygon}, inasmuch as {AB line} and {BD line} are in the plane through {BDA polygon} [Prop. 11.2], and in which(ever plane) {AB line} and {BD line} (are found), {DC line} is also (found).
Thus, {ED line} is at right-angles to {DC line}.
Hence, {CD line} is also at right-angles to {DE line}.
And {CD line} is also at right-angles to {BD line}.
Thus, {CD line} is standing at right-angles to two straight-lines, {DE line} and {DB line}, which meet one another, at the (point) of section, {D point}.
Hence, {CD line} is also at right-angles to the plane through {DE line} and {DB line} [Prop. 11.4].
And the plane through {DE line} and {DB line} is the reference (plane).
{CD line} is thus at right-angles to the reference plane.

Thus, if two straight-lines are parallel, and one of them is at right-angles to some plane, then the remaining (one) will also be at right-angles to the same plane.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 9
prose:
(Straight-lines) parallel to the same straight-line, and which are not in the same plane as it, are also parallel to one another.

For let {AB line} and {CD line} each be parallel to {EF line}, not being in the same plane as it.
I say that {AB line} is parallel to {CD line}.

For let some point {G point} have been taken at random on {EF line}.
And from it let {GH line} have been drawn at right-angles to {EF line} in the plane through {EF line} and {AB line}.
And let {GK line} have been drawn, again at right-angles to {EF line}, in the plane through {FE line} and {CD line}.

And since {EF line} is at right-angles to each of {GH line} and {GK line}, {EF line} is thus also at right-angles to the plane through {GH line} and {GK line} [Prop. 11.4].
And {EF line} is parallel to {AB line}.
Thus, {AB line} is also at right-angles to the plane through {HGK given} [Prop. 11.8].
So, for the same (reasons), {CD line} is also at right-angles to the plane through {HGK given}.
Thus, {AB line} and {CD line} are each at right-angles to the plane through {HGK given}.
And if two straight-lines are at right–angles to the same plane then the straight-lines are parallel [Prop. 11.6].
Thus, {AB line} is parallel to {CD line}.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 10
prose:
If two straight-lines joined to one another are (respectively) parallel to two straight-lines joined to one another, (but are) not in the same plane, then they will contain equal angles.

For let the two straight-lines joined to one another, {AB line} and {BC line}, be (respectively) parallel to the two straight-lines joined to one another, {DE line} and {EF line}, (but) not in the same plane.
I say that angle {ABC angle} is equal to (angle) {DEF angle}.

For let {BA line}, {BC line}, {ED line}, and {EF line} have been cut off (so as to be, respectively) equal to one another.
And let {AD line}, {CF line}, {BE line}, {AC line}, and {DF line} have been joined.

And since {BA line} is equal and parallel to {ED line}, {AD line} is thus also equal and parallel to {BE line} [Prop. 1.33].
So, for the same reasons, {CF line} is also equal and parallel to {BE line}.
Thus, {AD line} and {CF line} are each equal and parallel to {BE line}.
And straight-lines parallel to the same straight-line, and which are not in the same plane as it, are also parallel to one another [Prop. 11.9].
Thus, {AD line} is parallel and equal to {CF line}.
And {AC line} and {DF line} join them.
Thus, {AC line} is also equal and parallel to {DF line} [Prop. 1.33].
And since the two (straight-lines) {AB line} and {BC line} are equal to the two (straight-lines) {DE line} and {EF line} (respectvely), and the base {AC line} (is) equal to the base {DF line}, the angle {ABC angle} is thus equal to the (angle) {DEF angle} [Prop. 1.8].

Thus, if two straight-lines joined to one another are (respectively) parallel to two straight-lines joined to one another, (but are) not in the same plane, then they will contain equal angles.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 11
prose:
To draw a perpendicular straight-line from a given raised point to a given plane.

Let {A point} be the given raised point, and the given plane the reference (plane).
So, it is required to draw a perpendicular straight-line from point {A point} to the reference plane.

Let some random straight-line {BC line} have been drawn across in the reference plane, and let the (straight-line) {AD line} have been drawn from point {A point} perpendicular to {BC line} [Prop. 1.12].
If, therefore, {AD line} is also perpendicular to the reference plane then that which was prescribed will have occurred.
And, if not, let {DE line} have been drawn in the reference plane from point {D point} at right-angles to {BC line} [Prop. 1.11], and let the (straight-line) {AF line} have been drawn from {A point} perpendicular to {DE line} [Prop. 1.12], and let {GH line} have been drawn through point {F point}, parallel to {BC line} [Prop. 1.31].

And since {BC line} is at right-angles to each of {DA line} and {DE line}, {BC line} is thus also at right-angles to the plane through {ED line} and {DA line} [Prop. 11.4].
And {GH line} is parallel to it.
And if two straight-lines are parallel, and one of them is at right-angles to some plane, then the remaining (straight-line) will also be at right-angles to the same plane [Prop. 11.8].
Thus, {GH line} is also at right-angles to the plane through {ED line} and {DA line}.
And {GH line} is thus at right-angles to all of the straight-lines joined to it which are also in the plane through {ED line} and {AD line} [Def. 11.3].
And {AF line}, which is in the plane through {ED line} and {DA line}, is joined to it.
Thus, {GH line} is at right-angles to {FA line}.
Hence, {FA line} is also at right-angles to {HG line}.
And {AF line} is also at right-angles to {DE line}.
Thus, {AF line} is at right-angles to each of {GH line} and {DE line}.
And if a straight-line is set up at right-angles to two straight-lines cutting one another, at the point of section, then it will also be at right-angles to the plane through them [Prop. 11.4].
Thus, {FA line} is at right-angles to the plane through {ED line} and {GH line}.
And the plane through {ED line} and {GH line} is the reference (plane).
Thus, {AF line} is at right-angles to the reference plane.

Thus, the straight-line {AF line} has been drawn from the given raised point {A point} perpendicular to the reference plane.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to do.

title: Proposition 12
prose:
To set up a straight-line at right-angles to a given plane from a given point in it.

Let the given plane be the reference (plane), and {A point} a point in it.
So, it is required to set up a straight-line at right-angles to the reference plane at point {A point}.

Let some raised point {B point} have been assumed, and let the perpendicular (straight-line) {BC line} have been drawn from {B point} to the reference plane [Prop. 11.11].
And let {AD line} have been drawn from point {A point} parallel to {BC line} [Prop. 1.31].

Therefore, since {AD line} and {CB line} are two parallel straight-lines, and one of them, {BC line}, is at right-angles to the reference plane, the remaining (one) {AD line} is thus also at right-angles to the reference plane [Prop. 11.8].

Thus, {AD line} has been set up at right-angles to the given plane, from the point in it, {A point}.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to do.

title: Proposition 13
prose:
Two (different) straight-lines cannot be set up at the same point at right-angles to the same plane, on the same side.

For, if possible, let the two straight-lines {AB line} and {AC line} have been set up at the same point {A point} at right-angles to the reference plane, on the same side.
And let the plane through {BA line} and {AC line} have been drawn.
So it will make a straight cutting (passing) through (point) {A point} in the reference plane [Prop. 11.3].
Let it have made {DAE line}.
Thus, {AB line}, {AC line}, and {DAE line} are straight-lines in one plane.
And since {CA line} is at right-angles to the reference plane, it will thus also make right-angles with all of the straight-lines joined to it which are also in the reference plane [Def. 11.3].
And {DAE line}, which is in the reference plane, is joined to it.
Thus, angle {CAE angle} is a right-angle.
So, for the same (reasons), {BAE angle} is also a right-angle.
Thus, {CAE angle} (is) equal to {BAE angle}.
And they are in one plane.
The very thing is impossible.

Thus, two (different) straight-lines cannot be set up at the same point at right-angles to the same plane, on the same side.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 14
prose:
Planes to which the same straight-line is at right-angles will be parallel planes.

For let some straight-line {AB line} be at right-angles to each of the planes {CD polygon} and {EF polygon}.
I say that the planes are parallel.

For, if not, being produced, they will meet.
Let them have met.
So they will make a straight-line as a common section [Prop. 11.3].
Let them have made {GH line}.
And let some random point {K point} have been taken on {GH line}.
And let {AK line} and {BK line} have been joined.

And since {AB line} is at right-angles to the plane {EF polygon}, {AB line} is thus also at right-angles to {BK line}, which is a straight-line in the produced plane {EF polygon} [Def. 11.3].
Thus, angle {ABK angle} is a right-angle.
So, for the same (reasons), {BAK angle} is also a right-angle.
So the (sum of the) two angles {ABK angle} and {BAK angle} in the triangle {ABK polygon} is equal to two right-angles.
The very thing is impossible [Prop. 1.17].
Thus, planes {CD polygon} and {EF polygon}, being produced, will not meet.
Planes {CD polygon} and {EF polygon} are thus parallel [Def. 11.8].

Thus, planes to which the same straight-line is at right-angles are parallel planes.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 15
prose:
If two straight-lines joined to one another are parallel (respectively) to two straight-lines joined to one another, which are not in the same plane, then the planes through them are parallel (to one another).

For let the two straight-lines joined to one another, {AB line} and {BC line}, be parallel to the two straight-lines joined to one another, {DE line} and {EF line} (respectively), not being in the same plane.
I say that the planes through {AB line}, {BC line} and {DE line}, {EF line} will not meet one another (when) produced.

For let {BG line} have been drawn from point {B point} perpendicular to the plane through {DE line} and {EF line} [Prop. 11.11], and let it meet the plane at point {G point}.
And let {GH line} have been drawn through {G point} parallel to {ED line}, and {GK line} (parallel) to {EF line} [Prop. 1.31].

And since {BG line} is at right-angles to the plane through {DE line} and {EF line}, it will thus also make right-angles with all of the straight-lines joined to it, which are also in the plane through {DE line} and {EF line} [Def. 11.3].
And each of {GH line} and {GK line}, which are in the plane through {DE line} and {EF line}, are joined to it.
Thus, each of the angles {BGH angle} and {BGK angle} are right-angles.
And since {BA line} is parallel to {GH line} [Prop. 11.9], the (sum of the) angles {GBA angle} and {BGH angle} is equal to two right-angles [Prop. 1.29].
And {BGH angle} (is) a right-angle.
{GBA angle} (is) thus also a right-angle.
Thus, {GB line} is at right-angles to {BA line}.
So, for the same (reasons), {GB line} is also at right-angles to {BC line}.
Therefore, since the straight-line {GB line} has been set up at right-angles to two straight-lines, {BA line} and {BC line}, cutting one another, {GB line} is thus at right-angles to the plane through {BA line} and {BC line} [Prop. 11.4].
And planes to which the same straight-line is at right-angles are parallel planes [Prop. 11.14].
Thus, the plane through {AB line} and {BC line} is parallel to the (plane) through {DE line} and {EF line}.

Thus, if two straight-lines joined to one another are parallel (respectively) to two straight-lines joined to one another, which are not in the same plane, then the planes through them are parallel (to one another).
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 16
prose:
If two parallel planes are cut by some plane then their common sections are parallel.

For let the two parallel planes {AB polygon} and {CD polygon} have been cut by the plane {EFHG polygon}.
And let {EF line} and {GH line} be their common sections.
I say that {EF line} is parallel to {GH line}.

For, if not, being produced, {EF line} and {GH line} will meet either in the direction of {F point}, {H point}, or of {E point}, {G point}.
Let them be produced, as in the direction of {F point}, {H point}, and let them, first of all, have met at {K point}.
And since {EFK given} is in the plane {AB polygon}, all of the points on {EFK given} are thus also in the plane {AB polygon} [Prop. 11.1].
And {K point} is one of the points on {EFK given}.
Thus, {K point} is in the plane {AB polygon}.
So, for the same (reasons), {K point} is also in the plane {CD polygon}.
Thus, the planes {AB polygon} and {CD polygon}, being produced, will meet.
But they do not meet, on account of being (initially) assumed (to be mutually) parallel.
Thus, the straight-lines {EF line} and {GH line}, being produced in the direction of {F point}, {H point}, will not meet.
So, similarly, we can show that the straight-lines {EF line} and {GH line}, being produced in the direction of {E point}, {G point}, will not meet either.
And (straight-lines in one plane which), being produced, do not meet in either direction are parallel [Def. 1.23].
{EF line} is thus parallel to {GH line}.

Thus, if two parallel planes are cut by some plane then their common sections are parallel.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 17
prose:
If two straight-lines are cut by parallel planes then they will be cut in the same ratios.

For let the two straight-lines {AB line} and {CD line} be cut by the parallel planes {GH polygon}, {KL polygon}, and {MN polygon} at the points {A point}, {E point}, {B point}, and {C point}, {F point}, {D point} (respectively).
I say that as the straight-line {AE line} is to {EB line}, so {CF line} (is) to {FD line}.

For let {AC line}, {BD line}, and {AD line} have been joined, and let {AD line} meet the plane {KL polygon} at point {O point}, and let {EO line} and {OF line} have been joined.

And since two parallel planes {KL polygon} and {MN polygon} are cut by the plane {EBDO polygon}, their common sections {EO line} and {BD line} are parallel [Prop. 11.16].
So, for the same (reasons), since two parallel planes {GH polygon} and {KL polygon} are cut by the plane {AOFC polygon}, their common sections {AC line} and {OF line} are parallel [Prop. 11.16].
And since the straight-line {EO line} has been drawn parallel to one of the sides {BD line} of triangle {ABD polygon}, thus, proportionally, as {AE line} is to {EB line}, so {AO line} (is) to {OD line} [Prop. 6.2].
Again, since the straight-line {OF line} has been drawn parallel to one of the sides {AC line} of triangle {ADC polygon}, proportionally, as {AO line} is to {OD line}, so {CF line} (is) to {FD line} [Prop. 6.2].
And it was also shown that as {AO line} (is) to {OD line}, so {AE line} (is) to {EB line}.
And thus as {AE line} (is) to {EB line}, so {CF line} (is) to {FD line} [Prop. 5.11].

Thus, if two straight-lines are cut by parallel planes then they will be cut in the same ratios.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 18
prose:
If a straight-line is at right-angles to some plane then all of the planes (passing) through it will also be at right-angles to the same plane.

For let some straight-line {AB line} be at right-angles to a reference plane.
I say that all of the planes (passing) through {AB line} are also at right-angles to the reference plane.

For let the plane {DE polygon} have been produced through {AB line}.
And let {CE line} be the common section of the plane {DE polygon} and the reference (plane).
And let some random point {F point} have been taken on {CE line}.
And let {FG line} have been drawn from {F point}, at right-angles to {CE line}, in the plane {DE polygon} [Prop. 1.11].

And since {AB line} is at right-angles to the reference plane, {AB line} is thus also at right-angles to all of the straight-lines joined to it which are also in the reference plane [Def. 11.3].
Hence, it is also at right-angles to {CE line}.
Thus, angle {ABF angle} is a right-angle.
And {GFB angle} is also a right-angle.
Thus, {AB line} is parallel to {FG line} [Prop. 1.28].
And {AB line} is at right-angles to the reference plane.
Thus, {FG line} is also at right-angles to the reference plane [Prop. 11.8].
And a plane is at right-angles to a(nother) plane when the straight-lines drawn at right-angles to the common section of the planes, (and lying) in one of the planes, are at right-angles to the remaining plane [Def. 11.4].
And {FG line}, (which was) drawn at right-angles to the common section of the planes, {CE line}, in one of the planes, {DE polygon}, was shown to be at right-angles to the reference plane.
Thus, plane {DE polygon} is at right-angles to the reference (plane).
So, similarly, it can be shown that all of the planes (passing) at random through {AB line} (are) at right-angles to the reference plane.

Thus, if a straight-line is at right-angles to some plane then all of the planes (passing) through it will also be at right-angles to the same plane.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 19
prose:
If two planes cutting one another are at right-angles to some plane then their common section will also be at right-angles to the same plane.

For let the two planes {AB polygon} and {BC polygon} be at right-angles to a reference plane, and let their common section be {BD line}.
I say that {BD line} is at right-angles to the reference plane.

For (if) not, let {DE line} also have been drawn from point {D point}, in the plane {AB polygon}, at right-angles to the straight-line {AD line}, and {DF line}, in the plane {BC polygon}, at right-angles to {CD line}.

And since the plane {AB polygon} is at right-angles to the reference (plane), and {DE line} has been drawn at right-angles to their common section {AD line}, in the plane {AB polygon}, {DE line} is thus at right-angles to the reference plane [Def. 11.4].
So, similarly, we can show that {DF line} is also at right-angles to the reference plane.
Thus, two (different) straight-lines are set up, at the same point {D point}, at right-angles to the reference plane, on the same side.
The very thing is impossible [Prop. 11.13].
Thus, no (other straight-line) except the common section {DB line} of the planes {AB polygon} and {BC polygon} can be set up at point {D point}, at right-angles to the reference plane.

Thus, if two planes cutting one another are at right-angles to some plane then their common section will also be at right-angles to the same plane.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 20
prose:
If a solid angle is contained by three plane angles then (the sum of) any two (angles) is greater than the remaining (one), (the angles) being taken up in any (possible way).

For let the solid angle {A given} have been contained by the three plane angles {BAC angle}, {CAD angle}, and {DAB angle}.
I say that (the sum of) any two of the angles {BAC angle}, {CAD angle}, and {DAB angle} is greater than the remaining (one), (the angles) being taken up in any (possible way).

For if the angles {BAC angle}, {CAD angle}, and {DAB angle} are equal to one another then (it is) clear that (the sum of) any two is greater than the remaining (one).
But, if not, let {BAC angle} be greater (than {CAD angle} or {DAB angle}).
And let (angle) {BAE angle}, equal to the angle {DAB angle}, have been constructed in the plane through {BAC polygon}, on the straight-line {AB line}, at the point {A point} on it.
And let {AE line} be made equal to {AD line}. And {BEC line} being drawn across through point {E point}, let it cut the straight-lines {AB line} and {AC line} at points {B point} and {C point} (respectively).
And let {DB line} and {DC line} have been joined.

And since {DA line} is equal to {AE line}, and {AB line} (is) common, the two (straight-lines {AD line} and {AB line} are) equal to the two (straight-lines {EA line} and {AB line}, respectively).
And angle {DAB angle} (is) equal to angle {BAE angle}.
Thus, the base {DB line} is equal to the base {BE line} [Prop. 1.4].
And since the (sum of the) two (straight-lines) {BD line} and {DC line} is greater than {BC line} [Prop. 1.20], of which {DB line} was shown (to be) equal to {BE line}, the remainder {DC line} is thus greater than the remainder {EC line}.
And since {DA line} is equal to {AE line}, but {AC line} (is) common, and the base {DC line} is greater than the base {EC line}, the angle {DAC angle} is thus greater than the angle {EAC angle} [Prop. 1.25].
And {DAB angle} was also shown (to be) equal to {BAE angle}.
Thus, (the sum of) {DAB angle} and {DAC angle} is greater than {BAC angle}.
So, similarly, we can also show that the remaining (angles), being taken in pairs, are greater than the remaining (one).

Thus, if a solid angle is contained by three plane angles then (the sum of) any two (angles) is greater than the remaining (one), (the angles) being taken up in any (possible way).
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 21
prose:
Any solid angle is contained by plane angles (whose sum is) less [than] four right-angles.

Let the solid angle {A} be contained by the plane angles {BAC angle}, {CAD angle}, and {DAB angle}.
I say that (the sum of) {BAC angle}, {CAD angle}, and {DAB angle} is less than four right-angles.

For let the random points {B point}, {C point}, and {D point} have been taken on each of (the straight-lines) {AB line}, {AC line}, and {AD line} (respectively).
And let {BC line}, {CD line}, and {DB line} have been joined.
And since the solid angle at {B point} is contained by the three plane angles {CBA angle}, {ABD angle}, and {CBD angle}, (the sum of) any two is greater than the remaining (one) [Prop. 11.20].
Thus, (the sum of) {CBA angle} and {ABD angle} is greater than {CBD angle}.
So, for the same (reasons), (the sum of) {BCA angle} and {ACD angle} is also greater than {BCD angle}, and (the sum of) {CDA angle} and {ADB angle} is greater than {CDB angle}.
Thus, the (sum of the) six angles {CBA angle}, {ABD angle}, {BCA angle}, {ACD angle}, {CDA angle}, and {ADB angle} is greater than the (sum of the) three (angles) {CBD angle}, {BCD angle}, and {CDB angle}.
But, the (sum of the) three (angles) {CBD angle}, {BDC angle}, and {BCD angle} is equal to two right-angles [Prop. 1.32].
Thus, the (sum of the) six angles {CBA angle}, {ABD angle}, {BCA angle}, {ACD angle}, {CDA angle}, and {ADB angle} is greater than two right-angles.
And since the (sum of the) three angles of each of the triangles {ABC polygon}, {ACD polygon}, and {ADB polygon} is equal to two right-angles, the (sum of the) nine angles {CBA angle}, {ACB angle}, {BAC angle}, {ACD angle}, {CDA angle}, {CAD angle}, {ADB angle}, {DBA angle}, and {BAD angle} of the three triangles is equal to six right-angles, of which the (sum of the) six angles {ABC angle}, {BCA angle}, {ACD angle}, {CDA angle}, {ADB angle}, and {DBA angle} is greater than two right-angles.
Thus, the (sum of the) remaining three [angles] {BAC angle}, {CAD angle}, and {DAB angle}, containing the solid angle, is less than four right-angles.

Thus, any solid angle is contained by plane angles (whose sum is) less [than] four right-angles. (Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 22
prose:
If there are three plane angles, of which (the sum of any) two is greater than the remaining (one), (the angles) being taken up in any (possible way), and if equal straight-lines contain them, then it is possible to construct a triangle from (the straight-lines created by) joining the (ends of the) equal straight-lines.

Let {ABC angle}, {DEF angle}, and {GHK angle} be three plane angles, of which the sum of any) two is greater than the remaining (one), (the angles) being taken up in any (possible way)—(that is), {ABC angle} and {DEF angle} (greater) than {GHK angle}, {DEF angle} and {GHK angle} (greater) than {ABC angle}, and, further, {GHK angle} and {ABC angle} (greater) than {DEF angle}.
And let {AB line}, {BC line}, {DE line}, {EF line}, {GH line}, and {HK line} be equal straight-lines.
And let {AC line}, {DF line}, and {GK line} have been joined.
I say that that it is possible to construct a triangle out of (straight-lines) equal to {AC line}, {DF line}, and {GK line}—that is to say, that (the sum of) any two of {AC line}, {DF line}, and {GK line} is greater than the remaining (one).

Now, if the angles {ABC angle}, {DEF angle}, and {GHK angle} are equal to one another then (it is) clear that, (with) {AC line}, {DF line}, and {GK line} also becoming equal, it is possible to construct a triangle from (straight-lines) equal to {AC line}, {DF line}, and {GK line}.
And if not, let them be unequal, and let {KHL angle}, equal to angle {ABC angle}, have been constructed on the straight-line {HK line}, at the point {H point} on it.
And let {HL line} be made equal to one of {AB line}, {BC line}, {DE line}, {EF line}, {GH line}, and {HK line}.
And let {KL line} and {GL line} have been joined.
And since the two (straight-lines) {AB line} and {BC line} are equal to the two (straight-lines) {KH line} and {HL line} (respectively), and the angle at {B point} (is) equal to {KHL angle}, the base {AC line} is thus equal to the base {KL line} [Prop. 1.4].
And since (the sum of) {ABC angle} and {GHK angle} is greater than {DEF angle}, and {ABC angle} equal to {KHL angle}, {GHL angle} is thus greater than {DEF angle}.
And since the two (straight-lines) {GH line} and {HL line} are equal to the two (straight-lines) {DE line} and {EF line} (respectively), and angle {GHL angle} (is) greater than {DEF angle}, the base {GL line} is thus greater than the base {DF line} [Prop. 1.24].
But, (the sum of) {GK line} and {KL line} is greater than {GL line} [Prop. 1.20].
Thus, (the sum of) {GK line} and {KL line} is much greater than {DF line}.
And {KL line} (is) equal to {AC line}.
Thus, (the sum of) {AC line} and {GK line} is greater than the remaining (straight-line) {DF line}.
So, similarly, we can show that (the sum of) {AC line} and {DF line} is greater than {GK line}, and, further, that (the sum of) {DF line} and {GK line} is greater than {AC line}.
Thus, it is possible to construct a triangle from (straight-lines) equal to {AC line}, {DF line}, and {GK line}.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 23
prose:
To construct a solid angle from three (given) plane angles, (the sum of) two of which is greater than the remaining (one, the angles) being taken up in any (possible way).
So, it is necessary for the (sum of the) three (angles) to be less than four right-angles [Prop. 11.21].

Let {ABC angle}, {DEF angle}, and {GHK angle} be the three given plane angles, of which let (the sum of) two be greater than the remaining (one, the angles) being taken up in any (possible way), and, further, (let) the (sum of the) three (be) less than four right-angles.
So, it is necessary to construct a solid angle from (plane angles) equal to {ABC angle}, {DEF angle}, and {GHK angle}.

Let {AB line}, {BC line}, {DE line}, {EF line}, {GH line}, and {HK line} be cut off (so as to be) equal (to one another).
And let {AC line}, {DF line}, and {GK line} have been joined.
It is, thus, possible to construct a triangle from (straight-lines) equal to {AC line}, {DF line}, and {GK line} [Prop. 11.22].
Let (such a triangle), {LMN polygon}, have be constructed, such that {AC line} is equal to {LM line}, {DF line} to {MN line}, and, further, {GK line} to {NL line}.
And let the circle {LMN given} have been circumscribed about triangle {LMN polygon} [Prop. 4.5].
And let its center have been found, and let it be (at) {O point}.
And let {LO line}, {MO line}, and {NO line} have been joined.

I say that {AB line} is greater than {LO line}.
For, if not, {AB line} is either equal to, or less than, {LO line}.
Let it, first of all, be equal.
And since {AB line} is equal to {LO line}, but {AB line} is equal to {BC line}, and {OL line} to {OM line}, so the two (straight-lines) {AB line} and {BC line} are equal to the two (straight-lines) {LO line} and {OM line}, respectively.
And the base {AC line} was assumed (to be) equal to the base {LM line}.
Thus, angle {ABC angle} is equal to angle {LOM angle} [Prop. 1.8].
So, for the same (reasons), {DEF polygon} is also equal to {MON polygon}, and, further, {GHK polygon} to {NOL polygon}.
Thus, the three angles {ABC angle}, {DEF angle}, and {GHK angle} are equal to the three angles {LOM angle}, {MON angle}, and {NOL angle}, respectively.
But, the (sum of the) three angles {LOM angle}, {MON angle}, and {NOL angle} is equal to four right-angles.
Thus, the (sum of the) three angles {ABC angle}, {DEF angle}, and {GHK angle} is also equal to four right-angles.
And it was also assumed (to be) less than four right-angles.
The very thing (is) absurd.
Thus, {AB line} is not equal to {LO line}.
So, I say that {AB line} is not less than {LO line} either.
For, if possible, let it be (less).
And let {OP line} be made equal to {AB line}, and {OQ line} equal to {BC line}, and let {PQ line} have been joined.
And since {AB line} is equal to {BC line}, {OP line} is also equal to {OQ line}.
Hence, the remainder {LP line} is also equal to (the remainder) {QM line}.
{LM line} is thus parallel to {PQ line} [Prop. 6.2], and (triangle) {LMO polygon} (is) equiangular with (triangle) {PQO polygon} [Prop. 1.29].
Thus, as {OL line} is to {LM line}, so {OP line} (is) to {PQ line} [Prop. 6.4].
Alternately, as {LO line} (is) to {OP line}, so {LM line} (is) to {PQ line} [Prop. 5.16].
And {LO line} (is) greater than {OP line}.
Thus, {LM line} (is) also greater than {PQ line} [Prop. 5.14].
But {LM line} was made equal to {AC line}.
Thus, {AC line} is also greater than {PQ line}.
Therefore, since the two (straight-lines) {AB line} and {BC line} are equal to the two (straight-lines) {PO line} and {OQ line} (respectively), and the base {AC line} is greater than the base {PQ line}, the angle {ABC angle} is thus greater than the angle {POQ angle} [Prop. 1.25].
So, similarly, we can show that {DEF angle} is also greater than {MON angle}, and {GHK angle} than {NOL angle}.
Thus, the (sum of the) three angles {ABC angle}, {DEF angle}, and {GHK angle} is greater than the (sum of the) three angles {LOM angle}, {MON angle}, and {NOL angle}.
But, (the sum of) {ABC angle}, {DEF angle}, and {GHK angle} was assumed (to be) less than four right-angles.
Thus, (the sum of) {LOM angle}, {MON angle}, and {NOL angle} is much less than four right-angles.
But, (it is) also equal (to four right-angles).
The very thing is absurd.
Thus, {AB line} is not less than {LO line}.
And it was shown (to be) not equal either.
Thus, {AB line} (is) greater than {LO line}.

So let {OR line} have been set up at point {O point} at right-angles to the plane of circle {LMN given} [Prop. 11.12].
And let the (square) on {OR line} be equal to that (area) by which the square on {AB line} is greater than the (square) on {LO line} [Prop. 11.23 lem.].
And let {RL line}, {RM line}, and {RN line} have been joined.

And since {RO line} is at right-angles to the plane of circle {LMN given}, {RO line} is thus also at right-angles to each of {LO line}, {MO line}, and {NO line}.
And since {LO line} is equal to {OM line}, and {OR line} is common and at right-angles, the base {RL line} is thus equal to the base {RM line} [Prop. 1.4].
So, for the same (reasons), {RN line} is also equal to each of {RL line} and {RM line}.
Thus, the three (straight-lines) {RL line}, {RM line}, and {RN line} are equal to one another.
And since the (square) on {OR line} was assumed to be equal to that (area) by which the (square) on {AB line} is greater than the (square) on {LO line}, the (square) on {AB line} is thus equal to the (sum of the squares) on {LO line} and {OR line}.
And the (square) on {LR line} is equal to the (sum of the squares) on {LO line} and {OR line}.
For {LOR angle} (is) a right-angle [Prop. 1.47].
Thus, the (square) on {AB line} is equal to the (square) on {RL line}.
Thus, {AB line} (is) equal to {RL line}.
But, each of {BC line}, {DE line}, {EF line}, {GH line}, and {HK line} is equal to {AB line}, and each of {RM line} and {RN line} equal to {RL line}.
Thus, each of {AB line}, {BC line}, {DE line}, {EF line}, {GH line}, and {HK line} is equal to each of {RL line}, {RM line}, and {RN line}.
And since the two (straight-lines) {LR line} and {RM line} are equal to the two (straight-lines) {AB line} and {BC line} (respectively), and the base {LM line} was assumed (to be) equal to the base {AC line}, the angle {LRM angle} is thus equal to the angle {ABC angle} [Prop. 1.8].
So, for the same (reasons), {MRN angle} is also equal to {DEF angle}, and {LRN angle} to {GHK angle}.

Thus, the solid angle {R given}, contained by the angles {LRM angle}, {MRN angle}, and {LRN angle}, has been constructed out of the three plane angles {LRM angle}, {MRN angle}, and {LRN angle}, which are equal to the three given (plane angles) {ABC angle}, {DEF angle}, and {GHK angle} (respectively).
(Which is) the very thing it was required to do.

title: Lemma
prose:
And we can demonstrate, thusly, in which manner to take the (square) on {OR line} equal to that (area) by which the (square) on {AB line} is greater than the (square) on {LO line}.
Let the straight-lines {AB line} and {LO line} be set out, and let {AB line} be greater, and let the semicircle {ACB arc D} have been drawn around it.
And let {AC line}, equal to the straight-line {LO line}, which is not greater than the diameter {AB line}, have been inserted into the semicircle {ACB arc D} [Prop. 4.1].
And let {CB line} have been joined.
Therefore, since the angle {ACB angle} is in the semicircle {ACB arc D}, {ACB angle} is thus a right-angle [Prop. 3.31].
Thus, the (square) on {AB line} is equal to the (sum of the) squares on {AC line} and {CB line} [Prop. 1.47].
Hence, the (square) on {AB line} is greater than the (square) on {AC line} by the (square) on {CB line}.
And {AC line} (is) equal to {LO line}.
Thus, the (square) on {AB line} is greater than the (square) on {LO line} by the (square) on {CB line}.
Therefore, if we take {OR line} equal to {BC line} then the (square) on {AB line} will be greater than the (square) on {LO line} by the (square) on {OR line}.
(Which is) the very thing it was prescribed to do.

title: Proposition 24
prose:
If a solid (figure) is contained by (six) parallel planes then its opposite planes are both equal and parallelogrammic.

For let the solid (figure) {CDHG given} have been contained by the parallel planes {AC polygon}, {GF polygon}, and {AH polygon}, {DF polygon}, and {BF polygon}, {AE polygon}.
I say that its opposite planes are both equal and parallelogrammic.

For since the two parallel planes {BG polygon} and {CE polygon} are cut by the plane {AC polygon}, their common sections are parallel [Prop. 11.16].
Thus, {AB line} is parallel to {DC line}.
Again, since the two parallel planes {BF polygon} and {AE polygon} are cut by the plane {AC polygon}, their common sections are parallel [Prop. 11.16].
Thus, {BC line} is parallel to {AD line}.
And {AB line} was also shown (to be) parallel to {DC line}.
Thus, {AC polygon} is a parallelogram.
So, similarly, we can also show that {DF polygon}, {FG polygon}, {GB polygon}, {BF polygon}, and {AE polygon} are each parallelograms.

Let {AH line} and {DF line} have been joined.
And since {AB line} is parallel to {DC line}, and {BH line} to {CF line}, so the two (straight-lines) joining one another, {AB line} and {BH line}, are parallel to the two straight-lines joining one another, {DC line} and {CF line} (respectively), not (being) in the same plane.
Thus, they will contain equal angles [Prop. 11.10].
Thus, angle {ABH angle} (is) equal to (angle) {DCF angle}.
And since the two (straight-lines) {AB line} and {BH line} are equal to the two (straight-lines) {DC line} and {CF line} (respectively) [Prop. 1.34], and angle {ABH angle} is equal to angle {DCF angle}, the base {AH line} is thus equal to the base {DF line}, and triangle {ABH polygon} is equal to triangle {DCF polygon} [Prop. 1.4].
And parallelogram {BG polygon} is double (triangle) {ABH polygon}, and parallelogram {CE polygon} double (triangle) {DCF polygon} [Prop. 1.34].
Thus, parallelogram {BG polygon} (is) equal to parallelogram {CE polygon}.
So, similarly, we can show that {AC polygon} is also equal to {GF polygon}, and {AE polygon} to {BF polygon}.

Thus, if a solid (figure) is contained by (six) parallel planes then its opposite planes are both equal and parallelogrammic.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 25
prose:
If a parallelipiped solid is cut by a plane which is parallel to the opposite planes (of the parallelipiped) then as the base (is) to the base, so the solid will be to the solid.

For let the parallelipiped solid {ABCD given} have been cut by the plane {FG polygon} which is parallel to the opposite planes {RA polygon} and {DH polygon}.
I say that as the base {AEFV polygon} (is) to the base {EHCF polygon}, so the solid {ABFU given} (is) to the solid {EGCD given}.

For let {AH line} have been produced in each direction.
And let any number whatsoever (of lengths), {AK line} and {KL line}, be made equal to {AE line}, and any number whatsoever (of lengths), {HM line} and {MN line}, equal to {EH line}.
And let the parallelograms {LP polygon}, {KV polygon}, {HW polygon}, and {MS polygon} have been completed, and the solids {LQ given}, {KR given}, {DM given}, and {MT given}.

And since the straight-lines {LK line}, {KA line}, and {AE line} are equal to one another, the parallelograms {LP polygon}, {KV polygon}, and {AF polygon} are also equal to one another, and {KO polygon}, {KB polygon}, and {AG polygon} (are equal) to one another, and, further, {LX polygon}, {KQ polygon}, and {AR polygon} (are equal) to one another.
For (they are) opposite [Prop. 11.24].
So, for the same (reasons), the parallelograms {EC polygon}, {HW polygon}, and {MS polygon} are also equal to one another, and {HG polygon}, {HI polygon}, and {IN polygon} are equal to one another, and, further, {DH polygon}, {MY polygon}, and {NT polygon} (are equal to one another).
Thus, three planes of (one of) the solids {LQ given}, {KR given}, and {AU given} are equal to the (corresponding) three planes (of the others).
But, the three planes (in one of the soilds) are equal to the three opposite planes [Prop. 11.24].
Thus, the three solids {LQ given}, {KR given}, and {AU given} are equal to one another [Def. 11.10].
So, for the same (reasons), the three solids {ED given}, {DM given}, and {MT given} are also equal to one another.
Thus, as many multiples as the base {LF polygon} is of the base {AF polygon}, so many multiples is the solid {LU given} also of the the solid {AU given}.
So, for the same (reasons), as many multiples as the base {NF polygon} is of the base {FH polygon}, so many multiples is the solid {NU given} also of the solid {HU given}.
And if the base {LF polygon} is equal to the base {NF polygon} then the solid {LU given} is also equal to the solid {NU given}.
And if the base {LF polygon} exceeds the base {NF polygon} then the solid {LU given} also exceeds the solid {NU given}.
And if ({LF polygon}) is less than ({NF polygon}) then ({LU given}) is (also) less than ({NU given}).
So, there are four magnitudes, the two bases {AF polygon} and {FH polygon}, and the two solids {AU given} and {UH given}, and equal multiples have been taken of the base {AF polygon} and the solid {AU given}---(namely), the base {LF polygon} and the solid {LU given}---and of the base {HF polygon} and the solid {HU given}---(namely), the base {NF polygon} and the solid {NU given}.
And it has been shown that if the base {LF polygon} exceeds the base {FN polygon} then the solid {LU given} also exceeds the [solid] {NU given}, and if ({LF polygon} is) equal (to {FN polygon}) then ({LU given} is) equal (to {NU given}), and if ({LF polygon} is) less than ({FN polygon}) then ({LU given} is) less than ({NU given}).
Thus, as the base {AF polygon} is to the base {FH polygon}, so the solid {AU given} (is) to the solid {UH given} [Def. 5.5].
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 26
prose:
To construct a solid angle equal to a given solid angle on a given straight-line, and at a given point on it.

Let {AB line} be the given straight-line, and {A point} the given point on it, and {D given} the given solid angle, contained by the plane angles {EDC angle}, {EDF angle}, and {FDC angle}.
So, it is necessary to construct a solid angle equal to the solid angle {D given} on the straight-line {AB line}, and at the point {A point} on it.

For let some random point {F point} have been taken on {DF line}, and let {FG line} have been drawn from {F point} perpendicular to the plane through {ED line} and {DC line} [Prop. 11.11], and let it meet the plane at {G point}, and let {DG line} have been joined.
And let {BAL angle}, equal to the angle {EDC angle}, and {BAK angle}, equal to {EDG angle}, have been constructed on the straight-line {AB line} at the point {A point} on it [Prop. 1.23].
And let {AK line} be made equal to {DG line}.
And let {KH line} have been set up at the point {K point} at right-angles to the plane through {BA line} and {AL line} [Prop. 11.12].
And let {KH line} be made equal to {GF line}.
And let {HA line} have been joined.
I say that the solid angle at {A point}, contained by the (plane) angles {BAL angle}, {BAH angle}, and {HAL angle}, is equal to the solid angle at {D point}, contained by the (plane) angles {EDC angle}, {EDF angle}, and {FDC angle}.

For let {AB line} and {DE line} have been cut off (so as to be) equal, and let {HB line}, {KB line}, {FE line}, and {GE line} have been joined.
And since {FG line} is at right-angles to the reference plane (through {ED line} and {DC line}), it will also make right-angles with all of the straight-lines joined to it which are also in the reference plane [Def. 11.3].
Thus, the angles {FGD angle} and {FGE angle} are right-angles.
So, for the same (reasons), the angles {HKA angle} and {HKB angle} are also right-angles.
And since the two (straight-lines) {KA line} and {AB line} are equal to the two (straight-lines) {GD line} and {DE line}, respectively, and they contain equal angles, the base {KB line} is thus equal to the base {GE line} [Prop. 1.4].
And {KH line} is also equal to {GF line}.
And they contain right-angles (with the respective bases).
Thus, {HB line} (is) also equal to {FE line} [Prop. 1.4].
Again, since the two (straight-lines) {AK line} and {KH line} are equal to the two (straight-lines) {DG line} and {GF line} (respectively), and they contain right-angles, the base {AH line} is thus equal to the base {FD line} [Prop. 1.4].
And {AB line} (is) also equal to {DE line}.
So, the two (straight-lines) {HA line} and {AB line} are equal to the two (straight-lines) {DF line} and {DE line} (respectively).
And the base {HB line} (is) equal to the base {FE line}.
Thus, the angle {BAH angle} is equal to the angle {EDF angle} [Prop. 1.8].
So, for the same (reasons), {HAL angle} is also equal to {FDC angle}.
And {BAL angle} is also equal to {EDC angle}.

Thus, (a solid angle) has been constructed, equal to the given solid angle at {D given}, on the given straight-line {AB line}, at the given point {A point} on it.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to do.

title: Proposition 27
prose:
To describe a parallelepiped solid similar, and similarly laid out, to a given parallelepiped solid on a given straight-line.

Let the given straight-line be {AB line}, and the given parallelepiped solid {CD given}.
So, it is necessary to describe a parallelepiped solid similar, and similarly laid out, to the given parallelepiped solid {CD given} on the given straight-line {AB line}.

For, let a (solid angle) contained by the (plane angles) {BAH angle}, {HAK angle}, and {KAB angle} have been constructed, equal to solid angle at {C given}, on the straight-line {AB line} at the point {A point} on it [Prop. 11.26], such that angle {BAH angle} is equal to {ECF angle}, and {BAK angle} to {ECG angle}, and {KAH angle} to {GCF angle}.
And let it have been contrived that as {EC line} (is) to {CG line}, so {BA line} (is) to {AK line}, and as {GC line} (is) to {CF line}, so {KA line} (is) to {AH line} [Prop. 6.12].
And thus, via equality, as {EC line} is to {CF line}, so {BA line} (is) to {AH line} [Prop. 5.22].
And let the parallelogram {HB polygon} have been completed, and the solid {AL given}.

And since as {EC line} is to {CG line}, so {BA line} (is) to {AK line}, and the sides about the equal angles {ECG angle} and {BAK angle} are (thus) proportional, the parallelogram {GE polygon} is thus similar to the parallelogram {KB polygon}.
So, for the same (reasons), the parallelogram {KH polygon} is also similar to the parallelogram {GF polygon}, and, further, {FE polygon} (is similar) to {HB polygon}.
Thus, three of the parallelograms of solid {CD given} are similar to three of the parallelograms of solid {AL given}.
But, the (former) three are equal and similar to the three opposite, and the (latter) three are equal and similar to the three opposite.
Thus, the whole solid {CD given} is similar to the whole solid {AL given} [Def. 11.9].

Thus, {AL given}, similar, and similarly laid out, to the given parallelepiped solid {CD given}, has been described on the given straight-lines {AB line}.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to do.

title: Proposition 28
prose:
If a parallelepiped solid is cut by a plane (passing) through the diagonals of (a pair of) opposite planes then the solid will be cut in half by the plane.

For let the parallelepiped solid {AB given} have been cut by the plane {CDEF polygon} (passing) through the diagonals of the opposite planes {CF line} and {DE line}.
I say that the solid {AB given} will be cut in half by the plane {CDEF polygon}.

For since triangle {CGF polygon} is equal to triangle {CFB polygon}, and {ADE polygon} (is equal) to {DEH polygon} [Prop. 1.34], and parallelogram {CA polygon} is also equal to {EB polygon}---for (they are) opposite [Prop. 11.24]---and {GE polygon} (equal) to {CH polygon}, thus the prism contained by the two triangles {CGF polygon} and {ADE polygon}, and the three parallelograms {GE polygon}, {AC polygon}, and {CE polygon}, is also equal to the prism contained by the two triangles {CFB polygon} and {DEH polygon}, and the three parallelograms {CH polygon}, {BE polygon}, and {CE polygon}.
For they are contained by planes (which are) equal in number and in magnitude [Def. 11.10].
Thus, the whole of solid {AB given} is cut in half by the plane {CDEF polygon}.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 29
prose:
Parallelepiped solids which are on the same base, and (have) the same height, and in which the (ends of the straight-lines) standing up are on the same straight-lines, are equal to one another.

For let the parallelepiped solids {CM given} and {CN given} be on the same base {AB polygon}, and (have) the same height, and let the (ends of the straight-lines) standing up in them, {AG line}, {AF line}, {LM line}, {LN line}, {CD line}, {CE line}, {BH line}, and {BK line}, be on the same straight-lines, {FN line} and {DK line}.
I say that solid {CM given} is equal to solid {CN given}.

For since {CH polygon} and {CK polygon} are each parallelograms, {CB line} is equal to each of {DH line} and {EK line} [Prop. 1.34].
Hence, {DH line} is also equal to {EK line}.
Let {EH line} have been subtracted from both.
Thus, the remainder {DE line} is equal to the remainder {HK line}.
Hence, triangle {DCE polygon} is also equal to triangle {HBK polygon} [Props. 1.4, 1.8], and parallelogram {DG polygon} to parallelogram {HN polygon} [Prop. 1.36].
So, for the same (reasons), traingle {AFG polygon} is also equal to triangle {MLN polygon}.
And parallelogram {CF polygon} is also equal to parallelogram {BM polygon}, and {CG polygon} to {BN polygon} [Prop. 11.24].
For they are opposite.
Thus, the prism contained by the two triangles {AFG polygon} and {DCE polygon}, and the three parallelograms {AD polygon}, {DG polygon}, and {CG polygon}, is equal to the prism contained by the two triangles {MLN polygon} and {HBK polygon}, and the three parallelograms {BM polygon}, {HN polygon}, and {BN polygon}.
Let the solid whose base (is) parallelogram {AB polygon}, and (whose) opposite (face is) {GEHM polygon}, have been added to both (prisms).
Thus, the whole parallelepiped solid {CM given} is equal to the whole parallelepiped solid {CN given}.

Thus, parallelepiped solids which are on the same base, and (have) the same height, and in which the (ends of the straight-lines) standing up (are) on the same straight-lines, are equal to one another.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 30
prose:
Parallelepiped solids which are on the same base, and (have) the same height, and in which the (ends of the straight-lines) standing up are not on the same straight-lines, are equal to one another.

Let the parallelepiped solids {CM given} and {CN given} be on the same base, {AB polygon}, and (have) the same height, and let the (ends of the straight-lines) standing up in them, {AF line}, {AG line}, {LM line}, {LN line}, {CD line}, {CE line}, {BH line}, and {BK line}, not be on the same straight-lines.
I say that the solid {CM given} is equal to the solid {CN given}.

For let {NK line} and {DH line} have been produced, and let them have joined one another at {R point}.
And, further, let {FM line} and {GE line} have been produced to {P point} and {Q point} (respectively).
And let {AO line}, {LP line}, {CQ line}, and {BR line} have been joined.
So, solid {CM given}, whose base (is) parallelogram {ACBL polygon}, and opposite (face) {FDHM polygon}, is equal to solid {CP given}, whose base (is) parallelogram {ACBL polygon}, and opposite (face) {OQRP polygon}.
For they are on the same base, {ACBL polygon}, and (have) the same height, and the (ends of the straight-lines) standing up in them, {AF line}, {AO line}, {LM line}, {LP line}, {CD line}, {CQ line}, {BH line}, and {BR line}, are on the same straight-lines, {FP line} and {DR line} [Prop. 11.29].
But, solid {CP given}, whose base is parallelogram {ACBL polygon}, and opposite (face) {OQRP polygon}, is equal to solid {CN given}, whose base (is) parallelogram {ACBL polygon}, and opposite (face) {GEKN polygon}.
For, again, they are on the same base, {ACBL polygon}, and (have) the same height, and the (ends of the straight-lines) standing up in them, {AG line}, {AO line}, {CE line}, {CQ line}, {LN line}, {LP line}, {BK line}, and {BR line}, are on the same straight-lines, {GQ line} and {NR line} [Prop. 11.29].
Hence, solid {CM given} is also equal to solid {CN given}.

Thus, parallelepiped solids (which are) on the same base, and (have) the same height, and in which the (ends of the straight-lines) standing up are not on the same straight-lines, are equal to one another.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 31
prose:
Parallelepiped solids which are on equal bases, and (have) the same height, are equal to one another.

Let the parallelepiped solids {AE given} and {CF given} be on the equal bases {AB polygon} and {CD polygon} (respectively), and (have) the same height.
I say that solid {AE given} is equal to solid {CF given}.

{figure 1}So, let the (straight-lines) standing up, {HK line}, {BE line}, {AG line}, {LM line}, {PQ line}, {DF line}, {CO line}, and {RS line}, first of all, be at right-angles to the bases {AB polygon} and {CD polygon}.
And let {RT line} have been produced in a straight-line with {CR line}.
And let (angle) {TRU angle}, equal to angle {ALB angle}, have been constructed on the straight-line {RT line}, at the point {R point} on it [Prop. 1.23].
And let {RT line} be made equal to {AL line}, and {RU line} to {LB line}.
And let the base {RW polygon}, and the solid {XU given}, have been completed.

And since the two (straight-lines) {TR line} and {RU line} are equal to the two (straight-lines) {AL line} and {LB line} (respectively), and they contain equal angles, parallelogram {RW polygon} is thus equal and similar to parallelogram {HL polygon} [Prop. 6.14].
And, again, since {AL line} is equal to {RT line}, and {LM line} to {RS line}, and they contain right-angles, parallelogram {RX polygon} is thus equal and similar to parallelogram {AM polygon} [Prop. 6.14].
So, for the same (reasons), {LE polygon} is also equal and similar to {SU polygon}.
Thus, three parallelograms of solid {AE given} are equal and similar to three parallelograms of solid {XU given}.
But, the three (faces of the former solid) are equal and similar to the three opposite (faces), and the three (faces of the latter solid) to the three opposite (faces) [Prop. 11.24].
Thus, the whole parallelepiped solid {AE given} is equal to the whole parallelepiped solid {XU given} [Def. 11.10].
Let {DR line} and {WU line} have been drawn across, and let them have met one another at {Y point}.
And let {aTb line} have been drawn through {T line} parallel to {DY line}.
And let {PD line} have been produced to {a point}.
And let the solids {YX given} and {RI given} have been completed.
So, solid {XY given}, whose base is parallelogram {RX polygon}, and opposite (face) {Yc polygon}, is equal to solid {XU given}, whose base (is) parallelogram {RX polygon}, and opposite (face) {UV polygon}.
For they are on the same base {RX polygon}, and (have) the same height, and the (ends of the straight-lines) standing up in them, {RY line}, {RU line}, {Tb line}, {TW line}, {Se line}, {Sd line}, {Xc line} and {XV line}, are on the same straight-lines, {YW line} and {eV line} [Prop. 11.29].
But, solid {XU given} is equal to {AE given}.
Thus, solid {XY given} is also equal to solid {AE given}.
And since parallelogram {RUWT polygon} is equal to parallelogram {YT polygon}.
For they are on the same base {RT line}, and between the same parallels {RT line} and {YW line} [Prop. 1.35].
But, {RUWT polygon} is equal to {CD polygon}, since (it is) also (equal) to {AB polygon}.
Parallelogram {YT polygon} is thus also equal to {CD polygon}.
And {DT polygon} is another (parallelogram).
Thus, as base {CD polygon} is to {DT polygon}, so {YT polygon} (is) to {DT polygon} [Prop. 5.7].
And since the parallelepiped solid {CI given} has been cut by the plane {RF polygon}, which is parallel to the opposite planes (of {CI given}), as base {CD polygon} is to base {DT polygon}, so solid {CF given} (is) to solid {RI given} [Prop. 11.25].
So, for the same (reasons), since the parallelepiped solid {YI given} has been cut by the plane {RX polygon}, which is parallel to the opposite planes (of {YI given}), as base {YT polygon} is to base {TD polygon}, so solid {YX given} (is) to solid {RI given} [Prop. 11.25].
But, as base {CD polygon} (is) to {DT polygon}, so {YT polygon} (is) to {DT polygon}.
And, thus, as solid {CF given} (is) to solid {RI given}, so solid {YX given} (is) to solid {RI given}.
Thus, solids {CF given} and {YX given} each have the same ratio to {RI given} [Prop. 5.11].
Thus, solid {CF given} is equal to solid {YX given} [Prop. 5.9].
But, {YX given} was show (to be) equal to {AE given}.
Thus, {AE given} is also equal to {CF given}.

{figure 2}And so let the (straight-lines) standing up, {AG line}, {HK line}, {BE line}, {LM line}, {CO line}, {PQ line}, {DF line}, and {RS line}, not be at right-angles to the bases {AB polygon} and {CD polygon}.
Again, I say that solid {AE given} (is) equal to solid {CF given}.
For let {KN line}, {ET line}, {GU line}, {MV line}, {QW line}, {FX line}, {OY line}, and {SI line} have been drawn from points {K point}, {E point}, {G point}, {M point}, {Q point}, {F point}, {O point}, and {S point} (respectively) perpendicular to the reference plane (i.e., the plane of the bases {AB polygon} and {CD polygon}), and let them have met the plane at points {N point}, {T point}, {U point}, {V point}, {W point}, {X point}, {Y point}, and {I point} (respectively).
And let {NT line}, {NU line}, {UV line}, {TV line}, {WX line}, {WY line}, {YI line}, and {IX line} have been joined.
So solid {KV given} is equal to solid {QI given}.
For they are on the equal bases {KM polygon} and {QS polygon}, and (have) the same height, and the (straight-lines) standing up in them are at right-angles to their bases (see first part of proposition).
But, solid {KV given} is equal to solid {AE given}, and {QI given} to {CF given}.
For they are on the same base, and (have) the same height, and the (straight-lines) standing up in them are not on the same straight-lines [Prop. 11.30].
Thus, solid {AE given} is also equal to solid {CF given}.

Thus, parallelepiped solids which are on equal bases, and (have) the same height, are equal to one another.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 32
prose:
Parallelepiped solids which (have) the same height are to one another as their bases.

Let {AB given} and {CD given} be parallelepiped solids (having) the same height.
I say that the parallelepiped solids {AB given} and {CD given} are to one another as their bases.
That is to say, as base {AE polygon} is to base {CF polygon}, so solid {AB given} (is) to solid {CD given}.

For let {FH polygon}, equal to {AE polygon}, have been applied to {FG line} (in the angle {FGH angle} equal to angle {LCG angle}) [Prop. 1.45].
And let the parallelepiped solid {GK given}, (having) the same height as {CD given}, have been completed on the base {FH polygon}.
So solid {AB given} is equal to solid {GK given}.
For they are on the equal bases {AE polygon} and {FH polygon}, and (have) the same height [Prop. 11.31].
And since the parallelepiped solid {CK given} has been cut by the plane {DG polygon}, which is parallel to the opposite planes (of {CK given}), thus as the base {CF polygon} is to the base {FH polygon}, so the solid {CD given} (is) to the solid {DH given} [Prop. 11.25].
And base {FH polygon} (is) equal to base {AE polygon}, and solid {GK given} to solid {AB given}.
And thus as base {AE polygon} is to base {CF polygon}, so solid {AB given} (is) to solid {CD given}.

Thus, parallelepiped solids which (have) the same height are to one another as their bases.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 33
prose:
Similar parallelepiped solids are to one another as the cubed ratio of their corresponding sides.

Let {AB given} and {CD given} be similar parallelepiped solids, and let {AE line} correspond to {CF line}.
I say that solid {AB given} has to solid {CD given} the cubed ratio that {AE line} (has) to {CF line}.
